It seems Greek voters cast their votes against this long entrenched political system that's been called the hereditary democracy.
The political dynasties have run the country almost uninterruptedly for the past half-century.
And today's results could be seen as the beginning of a rejection of this system.
The worst off is Papandreou.
In the two previous socialist governments, he distinguished himself as one of the best foreign ministers in Europe.
Today, his party suffered its poor showings since the late 1970s.
For Karamanlis, the test would be whether he can manage to govern with his party alone or whether he'll have to call early elections once again.
Whatever the outcome, the analysts here were saying this evening that this is the beginning of an uncertain political transition.
NPR's Sylvia Poggioli talking with us from Athens.
Thank you, Sylvia.
Thank you, Noah.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED, from NPR News.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.
After a week of violence in Baghdad and obvious tension between the U.S.
and Iraqi governments, there is a little bit of relief to report on both fronts.
It was notably quiet in the city today.
A daytime curfew and a massive American military presence on the street may have made the end of the week more peaceful.
Top U.S.
and Iraqi officials have been arguing for the last several days over timelines and security and today the prime minister and the U.S.
Ambassador issued a joint statement.
In it, Iraq reaffirmed its commitment to a good and strong relationship with the United States.
NPR's Jamie Tarabay reports on the week in Baghdad.
This week Iraqis celebrated Eid al-Fitr, marking the end of the holy month of Ramadan.
On Monday, a U.S.
soldier of Iraqi descent traveled outside the fortified Green Zone to spend the holiday with Iraqi relatives.
His kidnapping prompted a major search by U.S.
forces in different parts of Baghdad.
U.S.
military spokesman Major General Bill Caldwell.
We have detained a number of personnel for possible connection with or knowledge of this kidnapping.
We're using all assets in our arsenal to find this American solider.
It had been an extremely bloody Ramadan for all.
On average, 40 Iraqis each day, more than 300 Iraqi soldiers and police were killed and the U.S.
military marked a grim milestone with at least 97 U.S.
troops killed this month, the highest death toll since last October.
This was bad news for the Bush administration and the Republican Party, fighting to win next month's midterm elections.
General George Casey, the top U.S.
military commander in Iraq told reporters this week Iraqi forces need another 12 to 18 months before they're ready to assume full control but that was only half the solution.
If the political leadership of Iraq can come together and resolve the basic issues that are dividing them, I believe we can make good progress on the security front.
And that, coupled with the already good progress with the Iraqi security forces I think can put Iraq in a very good place in 12 months.
The talk of timelines infuriated Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki, who claimed it was aimed more at American voters than Iraqis.

But in a marked change only two days later, Maliki issued a joint statement with American Ambassador Zalmay Khalilzad in which the Iraqi government essentially agreed to develop a timeline for progress.
In today's statement, both sides pledged to support each other.
As Ramadan ended, the violence in Baghdad eased but that may be because of the stepped up presence of U.S.
troops in the streets searching for the missing soldier.
Supermarket owner Anwar Kadan(ph) says his street in the Karada district has been closed off since Monday as U.S.
and Iraqi troops stop and search every car.
(Through Translator) They say an American was kidnapped?
So what?
Should the Iraqi people live in hell just for his sake?
We're harmed because of him.
Not everywhere was quiet.
Yesterday militiamen ambushed Iraqi police in Baquba, northeast of Baghdad.
Eighteen militiamen and 24 policemen were killed and at least seven other police were wounded.
Jamie Tarabay, NPR News, Baghdad.
Of the many tragedies to emerge from last year's deadly hurricanes, one of the more shocking was the bus fire that killed 23 people.
They were patients from a Texas nursing home being evacuated as Hurricane Rita approached.
Today transportation officials in Washington launched a two-day hearing designed to find out exactly what happened, and whether those deaths could've been avoided.
NPR's Rachel Martin reports.
Drew Wood and his colleague Jason Salisbury were on their way to work on Interstate 45 on September 23.
They told investigators today that they were just outside Wilmer, Texas, when they saw the burning bus on the side of the road.
They pulled over and immediately rushed into the bus and tried to drag people out.
After two or three entries, Wood says the flames and smoke became too much for them.
It didn't take long at all before it was engulfed with, you know, dark, thick smoke that you couldn't catch your breath.
Tried to crawl in there to grab one lady, but couldn't pull her out of the window.
So we went around to the front and that's when everything started blowing up.
Industries experts testified that the cause of the blaze was a faulty bearing on one of the wheels.
According to the manufacturer, Motorcoach Industries, the bearing had lost all its lubricant, and massive heat and friction caused the wheel to catch fire.
While much of the hearing is focused on the cause of the blaze, some witnesses questioned whether bus fires are on the rise and going underreported.
In the last, let's say, several years, there has been an increase in fires that I know of.
Larry Plochno is a transportation historian, and an expert on the motorcoach industry.
I have talked to several different organizations who - in the industry - who have had a concern about them.
There's absolutely no question that the number of fires is increasing.
That's it - national park along the coast of Maine.
